oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: M1917 U.S. Army helmet
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: A United States Army steel combat helmet offically designated M1917. Informally it was called a tin hat, shrapnel helmet, Tommy helmet, or doughboy helmet. The Germans laughingly called it a "salad bowl" because of its wide brim and shallow crown. At first, U.S. soldiers wore British Brodie helmets, but the American manufacture industry soon began producing its own helmets--based on the Brodie. The wide brim helped protect soldiers from falling debris and shrapnel from ordnance explosions.
